comment.author: 8798197@N04
comment._content: for all you wondering whether this arcade is still intact: the center of Rotterdam was bombed by the Germans on may 14th, 1940, to force the Netherlands to surrender to the German army. The city's center, including this structure was razed to the ground. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rotterdam_Blitz

comment.author: 23521940@N00
comment._content:
@ [http://www.flickr.com/photos/sunshineinthehills/]:
the arcade in Rotterdam doesn't exist anymore. It was destroyed during the Rotterdam bombing in WWII, may 1940.

There is an still existing arcade in Den Haag, Holland:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/rickll/1107684992/]

comment.author: 98572942@N00
comment._content: tbower wrote and displayed photo of the very comment I was thinking!  Though I have not been in residence at Cleveland, OH, in many decades, I did visit the landmark Arcade in 2007 when visiting city (Mother was in sharp decline at nursing home).  Those trips to NE Ohio revealed some treasures I had forgotten or, in several cases, did not already know!  Arcades were a great expression of commerce in the late 19th C.  Those cities that have them are most fortunate.  Surely they are far superior to the architecture of the malls of America and other urban sprawl structures that attract huge crowds in the practice of commerce and trade.

comment.author: 47154409@N06
comment._content: So nice to see some Dutch/Rotterdam architecture featured on your stream :-) With this shopping arcade, by design of architect J.C. van Wijk, the city council aimed for the grandeur of cities like Paris and Brussels. The 100m long passage contained shops at various levels, a coffee houses, a bath house and a hotel. In 1882, it was the first building in Rotterdam to be illuminated with electric lights.
